trans-unit.source: Introduction
trans-unit.target: Introduction

trans-unit.source: Motivation
trans-unit.target: Motivation

trans-unit.source: When you grant someone privileged access to your systems, you extend your trust boundary to that person.
trans-unit.target: When you grant someone privileged access to your systems, you extend your trust boundary to that person.

trans-unit.source: This is a risk -- administrators are an attack surface.
trans-unit.target: This is a risk -- administrators are an attack surface.

trans-unit.source: Insider attacks and stolen credentials are both real and common.
trans-unit.target: Insider attacks and stolen credentials are both real and common.

trans-unit.source: This is not a new problem.
trans-unit.target: This is not a new problem.

trans-unit.source: You are probably very familiar with the principle of least privilege, and you might use some form of role based access control (RBAC) with applications that provide it.
trans-unit.target: You are probably very familiar with the principle of least privilege, and you might use some form of role based access control (RBAC) with applications that provide it.

trans-unit.source: However, the effectiveness and manageability of these solutions are often limited by their broad scope and imprecision.
trans-unit.target: However, the effectiveness and manageability of these solutions are often limited by their broad scope and imprecision.

trans-unit.source: Furthermore, there are gaps in RBAC coverage.
trans-unit.target: Furthermore, there are gaps in RBAC coverage.

trans-unit.source: For example, in Windows, privileged access is largely a binary switch, forcing you to give unnecessary permissions when adding users to the Administrators group.
trans-unit.target: For example, in Windows, privileged access is largely a binary switch, forcing you to give unnecessary permissions when adding users to the Administrators group.

trans-unit.source: Just Enough Administration (JEA) provides a RBAC platform through PowerShell Remoting.
trans-unit.target: Just Enough Administration (JEA) provides a RBAC platform through PowerShell Remoting.

trans-unit.source: It allows specific users to perform specific administrative tasks on servers without giving them administrator rights.
trans-unit.target: It allows specific users to perform specific administrative tasks on servers without giving them administrator rights.

trans-unit.source: This allows you to fill in the gaps between your existing RBAC solutions, and simplifies management of those settings.
trans-unit.target: This allows you to fill in the gaps between your existing RBAC solutions, and simplifies management of those settings.

trans-unit.target: Check out the [README](./README.md) for the current supported operating systems and required downloads.

trans-unit.source: The computer is domain joined.
trans-unit.target: The computer is domain joined.

trans-unit.target: See the [Creating a Domain Controller](#creating-a-domain-controller) section to quickly set up a new domain on a server if you don't already have one.

trans-unit.target: Management with JEA occurs through PowerShell Remoting.

trans-unit.source: Identify Your Users or Groups
trans-unit.target: Identify Your Users or Groups

trans-unit.source: To show JEA in action, you need to identify the non-administrator users and groups you are going to use throughout this guide.
trans-unit.target: To show JEA in action, you need to identify the non-administrator users and groups you are going to use throughout this guide.

trans-unit.source: If you're using an existing domain, please identify or create some unprivileged users and groups.
trans-unit.target: If you're using an existing domain, please identify or create some unprivileged users and groups.

trans-unit.source: You will give these non-administrators access to JEA.
trans-unit.target: You will give these non-administrators access to JEA.

trans-unit.source: Anytime you see the `$NonAdministrator` variable in a top of a script, assign it to your selected non-administrator users or groups.
trans-unit.target: Anytime you see the `$NonAdministrator` variable in a top of a script, assign it to your selected non-administrator users or groups.

trans-unit.source: If you created a new domain from scratch, it's much easier.
trans-unit.target: If you created a new domain from scratch, it's much easier.

trans-unit.source: Please use the [Set Up Users and Groups](#set-up-users-and-groups) section in the appendix to create a non-administrator users and groups.
trans-unit.target: Please use the [Set Up Users and Groups](#set-up-users-and-groups) section in the appendix to create a non-administrator users and groups.

trans-unit.source: The default values of `$NonAdministrator` will be the groups created in that section.
trans-unit.target: The default values of `$NonAdministrator` will be the groups created in that section.

trans-unit.source: Enable PowerShell Module Logging (Optional)
trans-unit.target: Enable PowerShell Module Logging (Optional)

trans-unit.source: The following steps enable logging for all PowerShell actions on your system.
trans-unit.target: The following steps enable logging for all PowerShell actions on your system.

trans-unit.source: You don't need to enable this for JEA to work, but it will be useful in the [Reporting on JEA](#reporting-on-jea) section.
trans-unit.target: You don't need to enable this for JEA to work, but it will be useful in the [Reporting on JEA](#reporting-on-jea) section.

trans-unit.source: Open the Local Group Policy Editor
trans-unit.target: Open the Local Group Policy Editor

trans-unit.source: Navigate to "Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Windows PowerShell"
trans-unit.target: Navigate to "Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Windows PowerShell"

trans-unit.source: Double Click on "Turn on Module Logging"
trans-unit.target: Double Click on "Turn on Module Logging"

trans-unit.source: Click "Enabled"
trans-unit.target: Click "Enabled"

trans-unit.source: In the Options section, click on "Show" next to Module Names
trans-unit.target: In the Options section, click on "Show" next to Module Names

trans-unit.source: Type "*" in the pop up window.
trans-unit.target: Type "*" in the pop up window.

trans-unit.source: This means PowerShell will log commands from all modules.
trans-unit.target: This means PowerShell will log commands from all modules.

trans-unit.source: Click OK and apply the policy
trans-unit.target: Click OK and apply the policy

trans-unit.source: Note: you can also enable system-wide PowerShell transcription through Group Policy.
trans-unit.target: Note: you can also enable system-wide PowerShell transcription through Group Policy.

trans-unit.target: By using the "Credential" parameter, you have connected *as though you were* OperatorUser (or whichever account you used).

trans-unit.target: As you can tell, this is a very limited subset of the commands available in a normal PowerShell window (which can often include several thousand commands).

trans-unit.source: Specifically, it only shows the 7 default JEA cmdlets (Clear-Host, Exit-PSSession, Get-Command, Get-FormatData, Get-Help, Measure-Object, Out-Default, Select-Object) and the two commands explicitly included in the maintenance Role Capability file.
trans-unit.target: Specifically, it only shows the 7 default JEA cmdlets (Clear-Host, Exit-PSSession, Get-Command, Get-FormatData, Get-Help, Measure-Object, Out-Default, Select-Object) and the two commands explicitly included in the maintenance Role Capability file.

trans-unit.source: Next, let's take a look at the user context this session is operating under by invoking the custom function included in the maintenance Role Capability file:
trans-unit.target: Next, let's take a look at the user context this session is operating under by invoking the custom function included in the maintenance Role Capability file:

trans-unit.source: The output of this function shows the "ConnectedUser" as well as the "RunAsUser."
trans-unit.target: The output of this function shows the "ConnectedUser" as well as the "RunAsUser."

trans-unit.source: The connected user is the account that connected to the remote session (e.g. your account).
trans-unit.target: The connected user is the account that connected to the remote session (e.g. your account).

trans-unit.source: The connected user does not need to have administrator privileges.
trans-unit.target: The connected user does not need to have administrator privileges.

trans-unit.source: The "Run As" account is the account actually performing the privileged actions.
trans-unit.target: The "Run As" account is the account actually performing the privileged actions.

trans-unit.source: By connecting as one user, and running as a privileged user, we allow non-privileged users to preform specific administrative tasks without giving them administrative rights.
trans-unit.target: By connecting as one user, and running as a privileged user, we allow non-privileged users to preform specific administrative tasks without giving them administrative rights.

trans-unit.target: To demonstrate this in action, run the following command:

trans-unit.target: Normally, Restart-Service requires administrator privileges to be run.

trans-unit.source: With the JEA virtual account, however, we're able to run it using non-privileged credentials.
trans-unit.target: With the JEA virtual account, however, we're able to run it using non-privileged credentials.

trans-unit.source: So, JEA lets you get your job done using the commands you already use.
trans-unit.target: So, JEA lets you get your job done using the commands you already use.

trans-unit.target: But what about commands you *shouldn't* be allowed to use?

trans-unit.target: Try running a different command in the JEA session, like `Restart-Computer`, and notice that JEA prevents such commands from being executed.

trans-unit.source: PowerShell Session Configurations
trans-unit.target: PowerShell Session Configurations

trans-unit.source: When you used JEA in the above section, you started by running the following command:
trans-unit.target: When you used JEA in the above section, you started by running the following command:

trans-unit.source: While most of the parameters are self-explanatory, the *ConfigurationName* parameter may seem confusing at first.
trans-unit.target: While most of the parameters are self-explanatory, the *ConfigurationName* parameter may seem confusing at first.

trans-unit.source: That parameter specified the PowerShell Session Configuration to which you were connecting.
trans-unit.target: That parameter specified the PowerShell Session Configuration to which you were connecting.

trans-unit.source: *PowerShell Session Configuration* is a fancy term for a PowerShell endpoint.
trans-unit.target: *PowerShell Session Configuration* is a fancy term for a PowerShell endpoint.

trans-unit.source: It is the figurative "place" where users connect and get access to PowerShell functionality.
trans-unit.target: It is the figurative "place" where users connect and get access to PowerShell functionality.

trans-unit.source: Based on how you set up a Session Configuration, it can provide different functionality to connecting users.
trans-unit.target: Based on how you set up a Session Configuration, it can provide different functionality to connecting users.

trans-unit.source: For JEA, we use Session Configurations to restrict PowerShell to a limited set of functionality and to run as a privileged virtual account.
trans-unit.target: For JEA, we use Session Configurations to restrict PowerShell to a limited set of functionality and to run as a privileged virtual account.

trans-unit.source: You already have several registered PowerShell Session Configurations on your machine, each set up slightly differently.
trans-unit.target: You already have several registered PowerShell Session Configurations on your machine, each set up slightly differently.

trans-unit.source: Most of them come with Windows, but the "JEA_Demo" Session Configuration was set up in the [prerequisites](#prerequisites) section.
trans-unit.target: Most of them come with Windows, but the "JEA_Demo" Session Configuration was set up in the [prerequisites](#prerequisites) section.

trans-unit.source: You can see all registered Session Configurations by running the following command in an Administrator PowerShell prompt:
trans-unit.target: You can see all registered Session Configurations by running the following command in an Administrator PowerShell prompt:

trans-unit.source: PowerShell Session Configuration Files
trans-unit.target: PowerShell Session Configuration Files

trans-unit.source: You can make new Session Configurations by registering new *PowerShell Session Configuration Files*.
trans-unit.target: You can make new Session Configurations by registering new *PowerShell Session Configuration Files*.

trans-unit.source: Session Configuration Files have ".pssc" file extensions.
trans-unit.target: Session Configuration Files have ".pssc" file extensions.

trans-unit.source: You can generate Session Configuration Files with the New-PSSessionConfigurationFile cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: You can generate Session Configuration Files with the New-PSSessionConfigurationFile cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: Next, you are going to create and register a new Session Configuration for JEA.
trans-unit.target: Next, you are going to create and register a new Session Configuration for JEA.

trans-unit.source: Generate and Modify your PowerShell Session Configuration
trans-unit.target: Generate and Modify your PowerShell Session Configuration

trans-unit.source: Run the following command to generate a PowerShell Session Configuration "skeleton" file.
trans-unit.target: Run the following command to generate a PowerShell Session Configuration "skeleton" file.

trans-unit.source: **TIP:** Only the most common configuration settings are included in the skeleton file by default.
trans-unit.target: **TIP:** Only the most common configuration settings are included in the skeleton file by default.

trans-unit.source: Use the `-Full` parameter to include all applicable settings in the generated PSSC.
trans-unit.target: Use the `-Full` parameter to include all applicable settings in the generated PSSC.

trans-unit.source: Open the file in PowerShell ISE, or your favorite text editor.
trans-unit.target: Open the file in PowerShell ISE, or your favorite text editor.

trans-unit.source: Update the following fields in the file with the values below (remember to substitue in your own non-administrator security group):
trans-unit.target: Update the following fields in the file with the values below (remember to substitue in your own non-administrator security group):

trans-unit.source: Here is what each of those entries mean:
trans-unit.target: Here is what each of those entries mean:

trans-unit.source: The *SessionType* field defines preset default settings to use with this endpoint.
trans-unit.target: The *SessionType* field defines preset default settings to use with this endpoint.

trans-unit.source: *RestrictedRemoteServer* defines the minimal settings necessary for remote management.
trans-unit.target: *RestrictedRemoteServer* defines the minimal settings necessary for remote management.

trans-unit.source: By default, a *RestrictedRemoteServer* endpoint will expose Get-Command, Get-FormatData, Select-Object, Get-Help, Measure-Object, Exit-PSSession, Clear-Host, and Out-Default.
trans-unit.target: By default, a *RestrictedRemoteServer* endpoint will expose Get-Command, Get-FormatData, Select-Object, Get-Help, Measure-Object, Exit-PSSession, Clear-Host, and Out-Default.

trans-unit.source: It will set the *ExecutionPolicy* to *RemoteSigned*, and the *LanguageMode* to *NoLanguage*.
trans-unit.target: It will set the *ExecutionPolicy* to *RemoteSigned*, and the *LanguageMode* to *NoLanguage*.

trans-unit.source: The net effect of these settings is a secure and minimal starting point for configuring your endpoint.
trans-unit.target: The net effect of these settings is a secure and minimal starting point for configuring your endpoint.

trans-unit.source: The *RoleDefinitions* field assigns Role Capabilities to specific groups.
trans-unit.target: The *RoleDefinitions* field assigns Role Capabilities to specific groups.

trans-unit.source: It defines who can do what as a privileged account.
trans-unit.target: It defines who can do what as a privileged account.

trans-unit.source: With this field, you can specify the functionality available to any connecting user based on group membership.
trans-unit.target: With this field, you can specify the functionality available to any connecting user based on group membership.

trans-unit.source: This is the core of JEA's RBAC functionality.
trans-unit.target: This is the core of JEA's RBAC functionality.

trans-unit.source: In this example, you are exposing the pre-made "Demo" RoleCapability to members of the "Contoso\JEA_NonAdmin_Operator" group.
trans-unit.target: In this example, you are exposing the pre-made "Demo" RoleCapability to members of the "Contoso\JEA_NonAdmin_Operator" group.

trans-unit.source: The *RunAsVirtualAccount* field indicates that PowerShell should "run as" a Virtual Account at this endpoint.
trans-unit.target: The *RunAsVirtualAccount* field indicates that PowerShell should "run as" a Virtual Account at this endpoint.

trans-unit.source: By default, the Virtual Account is a member of the built in Administrators group.
trans-unit.target: By default, the Virtual Account is a member of the built in Administrators group.

trans-unit.source: On a domain controller, it is also a member of the Domain Administrators group by default.
trans-unit.target: On a domain controller, it is also a member of the Domain Administrators group by default.

trans-unit.source: Later in this guide, you will learn how to customize the privileges of the Virtual Account.
trans-unit.target: Later in this guide, you will learn how to customize the privileges of the Virtual Account.

trans-unit.source: The *TranscriptDirectory* field defines where "over-the-shoulder" PowerShell transcripts are saved after each remote session.
trans-unit.target: The *TranscriptDirectory* field defines where "over-the-shoulder" PowerShell transcripts are saved after each remote session.

trans-unit.source: These transcripts allow you to inspect the actions taken in each session in a readable way.
trans-unit.target: These transcripts allow you to inspect the actions taken in each session in a readable way.

trans-unit.source: For more information about PowerShell transcripts, check out this [blog post](http://blogs.msdn.com/b/powershell/archive/2015/06/09/powershell-the-blue-team.aspx).
trans-unit.target: For more information about PowerShell transcripts, check out this [blog post](http://blogs.msdn.com/b/powershell/archive/2015/06/09/powershell-the-blue-team.aspx).

trans-unit.source: Note: regular Windows Eventing also captures information about what each user ran with PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: Note: regular Windows Eventing also captures information about what each user ran with PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: Transcripts are just a bit more readable.
trans-unit.target: Transcripts are just a bit more readable.

trans-unit.source: Finally, save your changes to *JEADemo2.pssc*.
trans-unit.target: Finally, save your changes to *JEADemo2.pssc*.

trans-unit.target: Apply the PowerShell Session Configuration

trans-unit.source: Key Concepts
trans-unit.target: Key Concepts

trans-unit.source: **PowerShell Session Configuration**: Sometimes referred to as *PowerShell Endpoint*, this is the figurative "place" where users connect and get access to PowerShell functionality.
trans-unit.target: **PowerShell Session Configuration**: Sometimes referred to as *PowerShell Endpoint*, this is the figurative "place" where users connect and get access to PowerShell functionality.

trans-unit.source: You can list the registered Session Configurations on your system by running `Get-PSSessionConfiguration`.
trans-unit.target: You can list the registered Session Configurations on your system by running `Get-PSSessionConfiguration`.

trans-unit.source: When configured in a specific way, a PowerShell Session Configuration can be called a *JEA Endpoint*.
trans-unit.target: When configured in a specific way, a PowerShell Session Configuration can be called a *JEA Endpoint*.

trans-unit.source: **PowerShell Session Configuration File (.pssc)**: A file that, when registered, defines settings for a PowerShell Session Configuration.
trans-unit.target: **PowerShell Session Configuration File (.pssc)**: A file that, when registered, defines settings for a PowerShell Session Configuration.

trans-unit.source: It contains specifications for user roles that can connect to the endpoint, the "run as" Virtual Account, and more.
trans-unit.target: It contains specifications for user roles that can connect to the endpoint, the "run as" Virtual Account, and more.

trans-unit.source: **Role Definitions**: The field in a Session Configuration File that defines the Role Capabilities granted to connecting users.
trans-unit.target: **Role Definitions**: The field in a Session Configuration File that defines the Role Capabilities granted to connecting users.

trans-unit.source: It defines *who* can do *what* as a privileged account.
trans-unit.target: It defines *who* can do *what* as a privileged account.

trans-unit.source: This is the core of JEA's RBAC capabilities.
trans-unit.target: This is the core of JEA's RBAC capabilities.

trans-unit.source: **SessionType**: A field in a Session Configuration File that represents default settings for a Session Configuration.
trans-unit.target: **SessionType**: A field in a Session Configuration File that represents default settings for a Session Configuration.

trans-unit.source: For JEA endpoints, this must be set to RestrictedRemoteServer.
trans-unit.target: For JEA endpoints, this must be set to RestrictedRemoteServer.

trans-unit.source: **PowerShell Transcript**: A file containing an "over-the-shoulder" view of a PowerShell session.
trans-unit.target: **PowerShell Transcript**: A file containing an "over-the-shoulder" view of a PowerShell session.

trans-unit.source: You can set PowerShell to generate transcripts for JEA sessions using the TranscriptDirectory field.
trans-unit.target: You can set PowerShell to generate transcripts for JEA sessions using the TranscriptDirectory field.

trans-unit.source: For more information on transcripts, check out this [blog post](https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/magazine/ff687007.aspx).
trans-unit.target: For more information on transcripts, check out this [blog post](https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/magazine/ff687007.aspx).

trans-unit.target: In the above section, you learned that the "RoleDefinitions" field defined which groups had access to which Role Capabilities.

trans-unit.source: Introducing PowerShell Role Capabilities
trans-unit.target: Introducing PowerShell Role Capabilities

trans-unit.source: PowerShell Role Capabilities define "what" a user can do at a JEA endpoint.
trans-unit.target: PowerShell Role Capabilities define "what" a user can do at a JEA endpoint.

trans-unit.source: They detail a whitelist of things like visible commands, visible applications, and more.
trans-unit.target: They detail a whitelist of things like visible commands, visible applications, and more.

trans-unit.source: Role Capabilities are defined by files with a ".psrc" extension.
trans-unit.target: Role Capabilities are defined by files with a ".psrc" extension.

trans-unit.source: Key Concepts
trans-unit.target: Key Concepts

trans-unit.source: **Role Capability (.psrc)**: A file that define "what" a user can do at a JEA endpoint.
trans-unit.target: **Role Capability (.psrc)**: A file that define "what" a user can do at a JEA endpoint.

trans-unit.source: It details a whitelist of things like visible commands, visible console applications, and more.
trans-unit.target: It details a whitelist of things like visible commands, visible console applications, and more.

trans-unit.source: In order for PowerShell to detect Role Capabilities, you must put them in a "RoleCapabilities" folder in a valid PowerShell module.
trans-unit.target: In order for PowerShell to detect Role Capabilities, you must put them in a "RoleCapabilities" folder in a valid PowerShell module.

trans-unit.source: **PowerShell Module**: A package of PowerShell functionality.
trans-unit.target: **PowerShell Module**: A package of PowerShell functionality.

trans-unit.source: It can contain PowerShell functions, cmdlets, DSC Resources, Role Capabilities, and more.
trans-unit.target: It can contain PowerShell functions, cmdlets, DSC Resources, Role Capabilities, and more.

trans-unit.source: In order to be automatically loaded, PowerShell modules must be located under a path in `$env:PSModulePath`.
trans-unit.target: In order to be automatically loaded, PowerShell modules must be located under a path in `$env:PSModulePath`.

trans-unit.source: There are two important reasons to do this:
trans-unit.target: There are two important reasons to do this:

trans-unit.source: It is easy to expose give users more capabilities than you intend.
trans-unit.target: It is easy to expose give users more capabilities than you intend.

trans-unit.source: For example, `Set-ADUser` is an incredibly powerful and flexible command.
trans-unit.target: For example, `Set-ADUser` is an incredibly powerful and flexible command.

trans-unit.source: You may not want to expose everything it can do to help desk users.
trans-unit.target: You may not want to expose everything it can do to help desk users.

trans-unit.source: Even worse, it's possible to expose commands that allow users to escape JEA's restrictions.
trans-unit.target: Even worse, it's possible to expose commands that allow users to escape JEA's restrictions.

trans-unit.source: If this happens, JEA ceases to function as a security boundary.
trans-unit.target: If this happens, JEA ceases to function as a security boundary.

trans-unit.source: Please be careful when selecting commands.

trans-unit.source: Step 3: Confirm the Tasks Work with JEA
trans-unit.target: Step 3: Confirm the Tasks Work with JEA

trans-unit.source: Actually using those cmdlets may not be straightforward in the restricted JEA environment.
trans-unit.target: Actually using those cmdlets may not be straightforward in the restricted JEA environment.

trans-unit.source: JEA runs in *No Language* mode which, among other things, prevents users from using variables.
trans-unit.target: JEA runs in *No Language* mode which, among other things, prevents users from using variables.

trans-unit.source: In order to ensure that end users have a smooth experience, it's important to check for a few things.
trans-unit.target: In order to ensure that end users have a smooth experience, it's important to check for a few things.

trans-unit.source: As an example, consider `Set-ADAccountPassword`.
trans-unit.target: As an example, consider `Set-ADAccountPassword`.

trans-unit.source: The "-NewPassword" parameter requires a secure string.
trans-unit.target: The "-NewPassword" parameter requires a secure string.

trans-unit.source: Often, users create a secure string and pass it in as a variable (as below):
trans-unit.target: Often, users create a secure string and pass it in as a variable (as below):

trans-unit.source: However, No Language mode prevents the usage of variables.
trans-unit.target: However, No Language mode prevents the usage of variables.

trans-unit.source: You can get around this restriction in two ways:
trans-unit.target: You can get around this restriction in two ways:

trans-unit.source: You can require users run the command without assigning variables.
trans-unit.target: You can require users run the command without assigning variables.

trans-unit.source: This is easy to configure, but can be painful for the operators using the endpoint.
trans-unit.target: This is easy to configure, but can be painful for the operators using the endpoint.

trans-unit.source: Who wants to type this out every time you reset a password?
trans-unit.target: Who wants to type this out every time you reset a password?

trans-unit.source: You can wrap the complexity in a script or a function that you expose to end users.
trans-unit.target: You can wrap the complexity in a script or a function that you expose to end users.

trans-unit.source: Scripts and functions that you expose run in an unrestricted context; you can write functions that use variables and call other commands without any issue.
trans-unit.target: Scripts and functions that you expose run in an unrestricted context; you can write functions that use variables and call other commands without any issue.

trans-unit.source: This approach simplifies the end user experience, prevents errors, reduces required PowerShell knowledge, and reduces unintentionally exposing excess functionality.
trans-unit.target: This approach simplifies the end user experience, prevents errors, reduces required PowerShell knowledge, and reduces unintentionally exposing excess functionality.

trans-unit.source: The only downside is the cost of authoring and maintaining the function.
trans-unit.target: The only downside is the cost of authoring and maintaining the function.

trans-unit.source: **NoLanguage Mode**: When PowerShell is in "NoLanguage" mode, users may only run commands; they cannot use any language elements.
trans-unit.target: **NoLanguage Mode**: When PowerShell is in "NoLanguage" mode, users may only run commands; they cannot use any language elements.

trans-unit.source: For more information, run `Get-Help about_Language_Modes`.
trans-unit.target: For more information, run `Get-Help about_Language_Modes`.

trans-unit.source: **PowerShell Functions**: PowerShell functions are bits of PowerShell code that you can call by name.
trans-unit.target: **PowerShell Functions**: PowerShell functions are bits of PowerShell code that you can call by name.

trans-unit.source: For more information, run `Get-Help about_Functions`.
trans-unit.target: For more information, run `Get-Help about_Functions`.

trans-unit.source: **ValidateSet/ValidatePattern**: When exposing a command, you can restrict valid arguments for specific parameters.
trans-unit.target: **ValidateSet/ValidatePattern**: When exposing a command, you can restrict valid arguments for specific parameters.

trans-unit.source: A ValidateSet is a specific list of valid commands.
trans-unit.target: A ValidateSet is a specific list of valid commands.

trans-unit.source: A ValidatePattern is a regular expression that the arguments for that parameter must match.
trans-unit.target: A ValidatePattern is a regular expression that the arguments for that parameter must match.

trans-unit.source: Multi-machine Deployment and Maintenance
trans-unit.target: Multi-machine Deployment and Maintenance

trans-unit.source: At this point, you have deployed JEA to local systems several times.
trans-unit.target: At this point, you have deployed JEA to local systems several times.

trans-unit.source: Because your production environment probably consists of more than one machine, it's important to walk through the critical steps in the deployment process that must be repeated on each machine.
trans-unit.target: Because your production environment probably consists of more than one machine, it's important to walk through the critical steps in the deployment process that must be repeated on each machine.

trans-unit.source: High Level Steps:
trans-unit.target: High Level Steps:

trans-unit.source: Copy your modules (with Role Capabilities) to each node.
trans-unit.target: Copy your modules (with Role Capabilities) to each node.

trans-unit.source: Copy your session configuration files to each node.
trans-unit.target: Copy your session configuration files to each node.

trans-unit.source: Run `Register-PSSessionConfiguration` with your session configuration.
trans-unit.target: Run `Register-PSSessionConfiguration` with your session configuration.

trans-unit.source: Keep a copy of your session configuration and toolkits in a secure location.
trans-unit.target: Keep a copy of your session configuration and toolkits in a secure location.

trans-unit.source: As you make modifications, it's good to have a "single source of truth."
trans-unit.target: As you make modifications, it's good to have a "single source of truth."

trans-unit.target: Reporting on JEA

trans-unit.source: Because JEA allows non-privileged users to run in a privileged context, logging and auditing are extremely important.
trans-unit.target: Because JEA allows non-privileged users to run in a privileged context, logging and auditing are extremely important.

trans-unit.source: In this section, we'll run through the tools you can use to help you with logging and reporting.
trans-unit.target: In this section, we'll run through the tools you can use to help you with logging and reporting.

trans-unit.source: Reporting on JEA Actions
trans-unit.target: Reporting on JEA Actions

trans-unit.source: Over-the-Shoulder Transcription
trans-unit.target: Over-the-Shoulder Transcription

trans-unit.source: One of the quickest ways to get a summary of what's happening in a PowerShell session is to look over the shoulder of the person typing.
trans-unit.target: One of the quickest ways to get a summary of what's happening in a PowerShell session is to look over the shoulder of the person typing.

trans-unit.source: You see their commands, the output of those commands, and all is well.
trans-unit.target: You see their commands, the output of those commands, and all is well.

trans-unit.source: Or it's not, but at least you'll know.
trans-unit.target: Or it's not, but at least you'll know.

trans-unit.source: PowerShell transcription is designed to give you a similar view after the fact.
trans-unit.target: PowerShell transcription is designed to give you a similar view after the fact.

trans-unit.source: When using the "TranscriptDirectory" field in your Session Configuration, PowerShell will automatically record a transcript of all actions taken in a given session.
trans-unit.target: When using the "TranscriptDirectory" field in your Session Configuration, PowerShell will automatically record a transcript of all actions taken in a given session.

trans-unit.source: You can find transcripts from your sessions in this document here: "$env:ProgramData\JEAConfiguration\Transcripts"
trans-unit.target: You can find transcripts from your sessions in this document here: "$env:ProgramData\JEAConfiguration\Transcripts"

trans-unit.source: As you can tell, the transcript records information about the "Connected" user, the "Run As" user, the commands run in the session, and more.
trans-unit.target: As you can tell, the transcript records information about the "Connected" user, the "Run As" user, the commands run in the session, and more.

trans-unit.source: For more information about PowerShell transcription, check out [this blog post](http://blogs.msdn.com/b/powershell/archive/2015/06/09/powershell-the-blue-team.aspx).
trans-unit.target: For more information about PowerShell transcription, check out [this blog post](http://blogs.msdn.com/b/powershell/archive/2015/06/09/powershell-the-blue-team.aspx).

trans-unit.source: PowerShell Event Logs
trans-unit.target: PowerShell Event Logs

trans-unit.source: When you have module logging turned on, all PowerShell actions are also recorded in regular Windows Event logs.
trans-unit.target: When you have module logging turned on, all PowerShell actions are also recorded in regular Windows Event logs.

trans-unit.source: This is slightly messier to deal with when compared to transcripts, but the level of detail it gives you can be useful.
trans-unit.target: This is slightly messier to deal with when compared to transcripts, but the level of detail it gives you can be useful.

trans-unit.source: In the "PowerShell" operational log, Event ID 4104 will record each command invoked if you have enabled module logging.
trans-unit.target: In the "PowerShell" operational log, Event ID 4104 will record each command invoked if you have enabled module logging.

trans-unit.source: Other Event Logs
trans-unit.target: Other Event Logs

trans-unit.source: Unlike PowerShell logs and transcripts, other logging mechanisms will not capture the "Connected User".
trans-unit.target: Unlike PowerShell logs and transcripts, other logging mechanisms will not capture the "Connected User".

trans-unit.source: You will need to do some correlation between other logs and PowerShell logs to match up actions taken.
trans-unit.target: You will need to do some correlation between other logs and PowerShell logs to match up actions taken.

trans-unit.source: In the "Windows Remote Management" operational log, Event ID 193 will record the Connecting User's SID and Name, as well as the RunAs Virtual Account's SID to assist with this correlation.
trans-unit.target: In the "Windows Remote Management" operational log, Event ID 193 will record the Connecting User's SID and Name, as well as the RunAs Virtual Account's SID to assist with this correlation.

trans-unit.source: You may have also noticed that the name of the RunAs Virtual Account includes the connecting user's domain and username at the end.
trans-unit.target: You may have also noticed that the name of the RunAs Virtual Account includes the connecting user's domain and username at the end.

trans-unit.source: Key Concepts Used Throughout This Guide
trans-unit.target: Key Concepts Used Throughout This Guide

trans-unit.source: **PowerShell Remoting**: PowerShell remoting allows you to run PowerShell commands against remote machines.
trans-unit.target: **PowerShell Remoting**: PowerShell remoting allows you to run PowerShell commands against remote machines.

trans-unit.source: You can operate against one or many computers, and use either temporary or persistent connections.
trans-unit.target: You can operate against one or many computers, and use either temporary or persistent connections.

trans-unit.source: In this demo, you remoted into your local machine with an interactive session.
trans-unit.target: In this demo, you remoted into your local machine with an interactive session.

trans-unit.source: JEA restricts the functionality available through PowerShell remoting.
trans-unit.target: JEA restricts the functionality available through PowerShell remoting.

trans-unit.source: For more information about PowerShell remoting, run `Get-Help about_Remote`.
trans-unit.target: For more information about PowerShell remoting, run `Get-Help about_Remote`.

trans-unit.source: **"RunAs" User**: When using JEA, a non-administrator "runs as" a privileged "Virtual Account."
trans-unit.target: **"RunAs" User**: When using JEA, a non-administrator "runs as" a privileged "Virtual Account."

trans-unit.source: The Virtual Account only lasts the duration of the remote session.
trans-unit.target: The Virtual Account only lasts the duration of the remote session.

trans-unit.source: That is to say, it is created when a user connects to the endpoint, and destroyed when the user ends the session.
trans-unit.target: That is to say, it is created when a user connects to the endpoint, and destroyed when the user ends the session.

trans-unit.source: By default, the Virtual Account is a member of the local Administrators group.
trans-unit.target: By default, the Virtual Account is a member of the local Administrators group.

trans-unit.source: On a domain controller, it is a member of Domain Admins.
trans-unit.target: On a domain controller, it is a member of Domain Admins.

trans-unit.source: Virtual Accounts are local to the machine on which they are created, and do not have permissions outside of that machine.
trans-unit.target: Virtual Accounts are local to the machine on which they are created, and do not have permissions outside of that machine.

trans-unit.source: This means that they are not registered in Active Directory (no RID is assigned).
trans-unit.target: This means that they are not registered in Active Directory (no RID is assigned).

trans-unit.source: Additionally, if an allowed command/script tries to access resources outside of the local machine, it will be accessing those resources under the machine's identity, not the Virtual Account identity.
trans-unit.target: Additionally, if an allowed command/script tries to access resources outside of the local machine, it will be accessing those resources under the machine's identity, not the Virtual Account identity.

trans-unit.source: **"Connected" User**: The non-administrator user who connects to the JEA endpoint and to whom roles are assigned.
trans-unit.target: **"Connected" User**: The non-administrator user who connects to the JEA endpoint and to whom roles are assigned.

trans-unit.source: Any commands this user runs are run under the context of the RunAs User or virtual account.
trans-unit.target: Any commands this user runs are run under the context of the RunAs User or virtual account.

trans-unit.source: On Blacklisting
trans-unit.target: On Blacklisting

trans-unit.source: After playing around with JEA, you may be wondering if it is possible to blacklist commands.
trans-unit.target: After playing around with JEA, you may be wondering if it is possible to blacklist commands.

trans-unit.source: This is an understandable request, but it is not currently planned for JEA for the following reasons:
trans-unit.target: This is an understandable request, but it is not currently planned for JEA for the following reasons:

trans-unit.source: We designed JEA to limit operators to only the actions they need to do.
trans-unit.target: We designed JEA to limit operators to only the actions they need to do.

trans-unit.source: A blacklist is the opposite.
trans-unit.target: A blacklist is the opposite.

trans-unit.source: PowerShell command authors did not design PowerShell commands with the JEA in mind.
trans-unit.target: PowerShell command authors did not design PowerShell commands with the JEA in mind.

trans-unit.source: On a fresh install of Windows Server 2016, there are about 1520 commands immediately available.
trans-unit.target: On a fresh install of Windows Server 2016, there are about 1520 commands immediately available.

trans-unit.source: The threat models for these commands did not include the possibility that a user would be running commands as a more privileged account.
trans-unit.target: The threat models for these commands did not include the possibility that a user would be running commands as a more privileged account.

trans-unit.source: For example, certain commands allow for code injection by design (e.g. Add-Type and Invoke-Command in the core PowerShell module).
trans-unit.target: For example, certain commands allow for code injection by design (e.g. Add-Type and Invoke-Command in the core PowerShell module).

trans-unit.source: JEA can warn you when you expose the specific commands we know about, but we have not re-assessed every other command in Windows based on the new threat model.
trans-unit.target: JEA can warn you when you expose the specific commands we know about, but we have not re-assessed every other command in Windows based on the new threat model.

trans-unit.source: You must understand the capabilities of the commands you exposing through JEA.
trans-unit.target: You must understand the capabilities of the commands you exposing through JEA.

trans-unit.source: Furthermore, even if JEA blocked all commands with code-injection vulnerabilities, there is no guarantee that a malicious user would not be able to carry out a blacklisted action with another related command.
trans-unit.target: Furthermore, even if JEA blocked all commands with code-injection vulnerabilities, there is no guarantee that a malicious user would not be able to carry out a blacklisted action with another related command.

trans-unit.source: Unless you understand all of the commands that you are exposing, it is impossible for you to guarantee that a certain action is not possible.
trans-unit.target: Unless you understand all of the commands that you are exposing, it is impossible for you to guarantee that a certain action is not possible.

trans-unit.source: The burden is on you to understand what commands you are exposing, whether they are using a whitelist or a blacklist.
trans-unit.target: The burden is on you to understand what commands you are exposing, whether they are using a whitelist or a blacklist.

trans-unit.source: The number of commands a blacklist would expose is unmanageable, so JEA is implemented using whitelists instead.
trans-unit.target: The number of commands a blacklist would expose is unmanageable, so JEA is implemented using whitelists instead.

trans-unit.source: Considerations When Limiting Commands
trans-unit.target: Considerations When Limiting Commands

trans-unit.source: There is one important point to make about this step.
trans-unit.target: There is one important point to make about this step.

trans-unit.source: It is critical that all capabilities exposed through JEA are located in administrator-restricted areas.
trans-unit.target: It is critical that all capabilities exposed through JEA are located in administrator-restricted areas.

trans-unit.source: Non-administrator users should not have the capability to modify the scripts used through JEA endpoints.
trans-unit.target: Non-administrator users should not have the capability to modify the scripts used through JEA endpoints.

trans-unit.source: On a related note, it is critical that you do not give JEA users the ability to overwrite JEA configurations and whitelisted scripts within their JEA sessions.
trans-unit.target: On a related note, it is critical that you do not give JEA users the ability to overwrite JEA configurations and whitelisted scripts within their JEA sessions.

trans-unit.source: Be extremely careful when exposing commands like `Copy-Item`!
trans-unit.target: Be extremely careful when exposing commands like `Copy-Item`!

trans-unit.target: Common Role Capability Pitfalls

trans-unit.source: Functions vs. Cmdlets
trans-unit.target: Functions vs. Cmdlets

trans-unit.source: PowerShell commands written in PowerShell are PowerShell Functions.
trans-unit.target: PowerShell commands written in PowerShell are PowerShell Functions.

trans-unit.source: PowerShell commands written as specialized .NET classes are PowerShell Cmdlets.
trans-unit.target: PowerShell commands written as specialized .NET classes are PowerShell Cmdlets.

trans-unit.source: You can check the command type by running `Get-Command`.
trans-unit.target: You can check the command type by running `Get-Command`.

trans-unit.source: VisibleProviders
trans-unit.target: VisibleProviders

trans-unit.source: You will need to expose any providers your commands need.
trans-unit.target: You will need to expose any providers your commands need.

trans-unit.source: The most common is the FileSystem provider, but you may also need to expose others, like the Registry provider.
trans-unit.target: The most common is the FileSystem provider, but you may also need to expose others, like the Registry provider.

trans-unit.source: For an introduction to providers, check out this [Hey, Scripting Guy blog post](http://blogs.technet.com/b/heyscriptingguy/archive/2015/04/20/find-and-use-windows-powershell-providers.aspx).
trans-unit.target: For an introduction to providers, check out this [Hey, Scripting Guy blog post](http://blogs.technet.com/b/heyscriptingguy/archive/2015/04/20/find-and-use-windows-powershell-providers.aspx).

trans-unit.source: Be careful when exposing providers -- often, it is better to define your own function that works with the underlying providers than to directly expose the provider in a JEA session.
trans-unit.target: Be careful when exposing providers -- often, it is better to define your own function that works with the underlying providers than to directly expose the provider in a JEA session.

trans-unit.source: This way, you can still allow users to work with files, registry keys, etc. but retain control over **which* files and registry keys they can work with using custom validation logic.
trans-unit.target: This way, you can still allow users to work with files, registry keys, etc. but retain control over **which* files and registry keys they can work with using custom validation logic.
